column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=Some of the limitations inherent in the ASE processing, as described above, can be overcome by additional circuitry or processing provided within packet switch ICs, for example, to pre-process packets before they enter the packet forwarding circuitry and/or to post-process packets after they leave the packet forwarding circuitry.
#Text=One packet switch IC optimization technique is to pre-process data packets to remove the payload in the data packet prior to forwarding the data packet.
#Text=Because many network performance monitoring and security applications only look at packet headers, the payload of the packet is not required.

#Text=An intelligent pre-processing circuit can be configured to take advantage of this by removing the payload from some (or all) of the packets before these packets enter the packet forwarding circuitry.

#Text=Of course, in addition to removing the payload, the pre-processing circuitry can also be configured to recalculate error correction features such as the CRC-32 Ethernet frame checksum included in Ethernet data packets.

#Text=Because the packet headers usually represent a small fraction of the overall data in the packet, this payload removal technique provides the significant advantage of greatly reducing the bandwidth of data that the packet forwarding circuitry and downstream tools must process.

#Text=One disadvantage of this technique is that it removes the payload, so that some monitoring tools (such as intrusion detection systems and virus scanners) could not be used once the payload is removed.
#Text=As such, payload removal could be done selectively based on the criteria selected within the pre-processing circuit.
#Text=Any payload reduction, however, would direct less traffic to the egress buffer thereby reducing loading at the egress buffer.
#Text=Further, if the length of the original packet is important but the payload is not, the payload can be removed, and the original packet length can be added to the packet.
#Text=For example, the original packet length can be appended just before the CRC-32 checksum so that an egress post-processing step could pad the egress packets back up the proper size.
#Text=This would allow a downstream monitoring tool to see the correct number of bytes, while still reducing the processing load.
#Text=Another packet switch optimization technique is to provide post-processing rate adaptation.

#Text=Because the instrument or tool port is often configured to operate at a lower rate than the maximum possible rate, the tool optimizer may drop packets that would not be dropped if the tool port were configured to operate at a higher rate.

#Text=To alleviate this problem, rate-adaptation can be included in a post-processing stage whereby the ports on the packet switch always operate at the highest configurable data rate after forwarding by the packet switch.
#Text=This adaptation of the data rate to its highest level helps to ensures that egress port congestion caused by the processing algorithm, such as the ASE processing described above, is minimized.
#Text=For example, additional circuitry could be provided to receive the higher data rate packets and to remove the idle time between packets.
#Text=This additional circuitry could also provide a larger egress buffer than is available in commercially available packet switching integrated circuits today.
#Text=If desired, this additional circuitry could take the form of external circuitry connected to the tool port of the tool optimizer and also to the destination tool.

#Text=In other words, this external circuitry provides an adapter that can receive data at a higher rate from the tool optimizer, buffer this data, and then provide it to the tool optimizer at a lower rate.

#Text=This rate adaptation circuitry thereby allows the tool optimizer ports to operate at a higher rate, when needed, to reduce the chance of buffer overflow in the egress buffers of the packet switch integrated circuit.

#Text=A further packet switch optimization technique to help alleviate the egress buffer overflow issue is to allow the user to assign CoS (Class of Service) to each ingress filter engine's forwarded packets.
#Text=This CoS labeling would allow a prioritization of which packets should be discarded first should an egress buffer experience overflow.
#Text=Currently available packet switch integrated circuits include the capability to assign all packets forwarded by an ingress filter engine (i.e., all filter matches) to a particular CoS.
#Text=Commercial packet switch circuits, however, do not currently have the capability to assign a unique CoS to filter matches based on the destination port to which they are being forwarded.

#Text=This latter capability would be very useful within the ASE processing above because filter rules forwarding to directly connected destination ports could then assign those packets to a high priority CoS to ensure they were dropped only when the sum of all directly attached filter matches exceeded the port's line rate.

#Text=Similarly, overlapping filter matches forwarded to destination ports that were not directly connected could be assigned a user defined CoS priority to ensure those packets were dropped first in case the egress buffer overflowed.
#Text=Further modifications and alternative embodiments of this invention will be apparent to those skilled in the art in view of this description.
#Text=It will be recognized, therefore, that the present invention is not limited by these example arrangements.
#Text=Accordingly, this description is to be construed as illustrative only and is for the purpose of teaching those skilled in the art the manner of carrying out the invention.
#Text=It is to be understood that the forms of the invention herein shown and described are to be taken as the presently preferred embodiments.
#Text=Various changes may be made in the implementations and architectures.

#Text=For example, equivalent elements may be substituted for those illustrated and described herein, and certain features of the invention may be utilized independently of the use of other features, all as would be apparent to one skilled in the art after having the benefit of this description of the invention.
